barbicanclient/v1/client.py.message:
We still want to execute this code.  Basically, this code verifies that the client software supports the version requested.

This allows us to error out correctly (and before even trying to contact the server) if:
1. the version is malformed - like foo, or ver1.2 for instance
2. the version is not supported by the client

Notice that the client has a list of supported microversions above in lines 29,30.  So, if someone asks for version 1.9  this will fail here first because the client does not support version 1.9
Done
"support" twice?
Done
s/_get_microversion/_get_max_microversion/
Done
get_max_supported_version

This isn't quite right.  You need to support the maximum version that is supported by both the client and server.  For example, if the server supports versions 1.0 to 1.2 (min = 1.0, max = 1.2) and the client supports (see line 30 above) 1.0 and 1.1, then you should return 1.1.

Right now, you will return 1.2 - which is incorrect.

That does of course beg the question of what to do if there is no overlap between the server and client versions  -- if there isn't you'll need to error out accordingly.

So, the logic is:

if microversion is None:
   iterate through client_supported_versions from highest to lowest:
       if client_version in max, min
          return client_version
   error_out "No match between client and server
Done

for version in ("1.1¨, "1.0"):

    ...

It is better to fail fast if the microversion passed in is invalid.

So, I'd do something like this:

 if microversion is not None:
     # check if requested microversion is well formed and something we understand

     if normalized not in _SUPPORTED_MICROVERSIONS:
         raise ValueError("Invalid microversion {}".format(microversion))
     microversion = discover.version_to_string(normalized) 
     
 min_ver, max_ver = self._get_min_max_server_supported_microversion(
     session, endpoint, version, service_type, service_name, interface,
     region_name)
          
 if microversion is None:
     for client_version in _SUPPORTED_MICROVERSIONS[::-1]:
     if discover.version_between(min_ver, max_ver, client_version):

        "Couldn't find a version supported by both client and server")
  else:
     if ! discover.version_between(min_ver, max_ver, microversion):
         raise ValueError(
            "Invalid microversion {}: Microversion requested is not "
            "supported by the server".format(microversion))
     return microversion

os_net_config/impl_ifcfg.py.message: the command to apply ethtool_opts is `ethtool -s <devname> <ethtool_opts>`. here the '-s <devname>' is missing

On man page of ethtool, -s <devname> is only applicable to 'ethtool -s devname [speed N] [duplex half|full]...' for changing settings, like speed, duplex, autoneg. In this code, it accepts any ethtool commands to assign something to the device. So, I think we don't have '-s <devname>' here.

I don't think we can apply ethtool commands without restart if the device is referred to as ${DEVICE} or $DEVICE. That works in ifcfg files because the DEVICE=<dev> line in the ifcfg assigns the device name as the value of $DEVICE or ${DEVICE}. If we are running ethtool using execute() then that value won't exist. Instead I think we should replace the value of $DEVICE or ${DEVICE} before running the command. See below in activate for loop (after L1804).

Here also we can't use $DEVICE or ${DEVICE} for commands that we run using execute(). We need to use the real device name.

This should be commands.append("-s %s %s" % (device_name, command_opts))

After we split the commands I think we need to replace the $DEVICE or ${DEVICE} with the real interface name (see above comment). This list comprehension should replace either variable with the real device name:

args = [interface[0] if item in ["${DEVICE}", "$DEVICE"] else item for item in args]
When the commands returned can be a empty list or valid list, checking with None is not required.

Hi Karthik, Thank you for your comment! I understand that. I'm trying to create a new patch.

Got it, but ifcfg scripts support ETHTOOL_OPTS in both styles. So we also will need similar mechanism in os-net-config.
https://github.com/fedora-sysv/initscripts/blob/main/network-scripts/network-functions#L198

ETHTOOL_OPTS supports these formats given below. We need to support all of these.
ETHTOOL_OPTS="speed 100 duplex full autoneg off"
ETHTOOL_OPTS="-G ${DEVICE} rx 4096"
ETHTOOL_OPTS="-G ${DEVICE} rx 4096; -G ${DEVICE} -A autoneg on"

As I commented in impl_ifcfg.py, this change doesn't focus on changing settings for speed, duplex, autoneg or else. The intention of this modification accepts any ethtool command options for setting anything to the device.

You also need to add the testing and documentation section.
do we need additional option for that? Can't we use existing one for both IPv4 and IPv6 traffic?

I believe it would be non-trivial (therefore needing docs) if "floating_ip" referred to ipv6 addresses too. Therefore enable_distributed_ipv6 seems more self-explanatory to me.

In addition if we re-used enable_distributed_floating_ip then in some releases this will mean distributed for v4 but not for v6, but in later releases distributed for both. Which would change behavior during an upgrade.

The way to configure one feature like this is similar to distributed floating IP. However, the dnat NAT rule for FIP IPv4 needs to be used integrated with the router the snat rule because local_ip for IPv4 needs to be masquerade. For the IPv6 world, the local_ip is a global address (don't masquerade) and the IPv6 traffic should be globally routed between the VM IPv6 GUA and the external network. For the VM's IPv6 to be accessible from the outside world, it needs to be advertised in the border equipment's routing tables (usually via BGP), and this task can be done in different ways, e.g. with FRR or using n-d-r. The IPv4 traffic does not work the same and does not need an additional backend to control the DVR.
I agree with this question, thanks for the comments.

I'm not sure if You are aware but for IPv4 FIPs we have merged spec https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/846987 which proposed to add "distributed" attribute to FIP and let users control each FIP separatelly if it should be distributed or not.
Do You think we can do something similar somehow for IPv6 addresses?

I think it's possible. I understand this requirement to make it configurable for IPv4 but talking about IPv6, we need a backend to propagate global IPv6 subnet addresses. When we use n-d-r, it propagates the subnets via bgp to the border informing that the next-hop is the IP/MAC of the router's external port and this causes the traffic to be always centralized on it (with no option to choose centralized or distributed). If we use an approach like the one I'm proposing without n-d-r and leaving the BGP management config to the IP fabric, possibly with FRR. It will be possible to choose between centralized or distributed, yes, just add the NAT rule or not. The FRR that runs on the chassis can forward the traffic directly to the spine/leaf/border (if you have the rule NAT on the chassis - using FRR), or forward the traffic to the chassis where the router's external port resides (via Geneve) so that this chassis forwards to the IP fabric/external world. The important point here is that this solution is not compatible with n-d-r, as n-d-r publishes the path to the border centrally.

The proposed version implemented for testing is based on a global config to enable the DVR for IPv6, to make it configurable, it would first be necessary to evaluate where to put this information since the idea here is different from the FIP as there is no specific table for IPv6. Today, the IPv6 information used for the NAT rule is linked to the VM's subnet fixed_ips. What would be the recommendation? do I keep the current implementation or do we discuss where to store this information? NOTE: I still don't understand how this will be managed in the case of FIP IPv4, from what I've seen it's not implemented yet for reference.

As discussed by emails with Rodolfo, I'd like to open a discussion about making a generic Neutron-OVN agent that provides an interface for various functionality - like for example what the proposed OVN monitor does for QoS and HWOL. It can also (in the next cycles) consume the metadata agent and also for example replace current agent API implementation with rpc methods.

This suggestion is to kick-off a discussion about this approach, I think having relevant data in memory for all services can be beneficial.

For now, I think we should stick to the ovsdb communication agent. We can implement the RPC part (even a new agent) in future releases/RFEs.

So, if I'm reading you well, the idea is:
1) To create this OVN agent (generic) with an extensible interface, same as other agents. I was thinking about using the ``agent.agent_extensions_manager.AgentExtensionsManager`` class to implement it, same as in other ML2 agents.
2) Implement the QoS HWOL feature.
3) In future releases, move the metadata functionality to this "OVN agent".

I'll push a new PS to portray these ideas.

I think it's a really good point about the rpc (mq) with the agent. I'm not familiar in details about scaling issues with the mq. I know what I'm gonna say is out of context of this spec, so probably this spec should not think about rpc at all and just provide the pluggable agent functionality + implementation of HWOL configuration.

OT: imho the rpc may be good for things like agent API similarly to what ml2/ovs agents do - periodically calling and rpc method to update timestamps in the agent DB. Another thing where I think rpc could be good is metering - we've talked a couple of times with operators about metering capabilities for OVN. Given that this is OpenStack specific rather than CMS (maybe OVN can provide stats too) but reporting stats back to server is something may happen in future too. Generally one-way periodic communication from agent towards server is something what I think could be good for rpc as it won't cause any side-effects. Just wanted to share my opinion on rpc with agents :)

I think it's a good idea to start with a generic agent that can be used for later features also requiring an agent.

I believe the following combinations make sense:
a) a general-purpose but ml2/ovn-specific agent that uses ovsdb to communicate
b) a general-purpose but non-ml2/ovn-specific agent that uses the mq (rpc) to communicate

My understanding was that ovn architecture preferred communication via ovsdb over rpc partially because of scaling reasons. (Though I don't remember reading an in-practice comparison of its scaling properties compared to the previous rpc approach demonstrating that it actually scales differently.) However if we add an rpc-using agent to ovn, then ovn will have both communication methods' scaling bottlenecks. For this reason I'm leaning into the direction of keeping all communication inside ovsdb. Then ovn would have the scaling bottlenecks of only one communication method.

Thanks for starting this discussion.

I like the idea of a single OVN agent instead of multiple ones. As long as it's engineered in a way that is easy to extend (a well defined API) in a plugin-in style where functionalities can be enabled/disabled easily.

A single agent does help deployers as new functionalities no longer need another service running. It also helps with monitoring such service.

And the main thing for me, at least with OVN in mind, is scalability because we really struggle to scale OVSDB and having multiple agents almost always translate into more connections to the OVSDB databases for each service. A single agent could benefit from a single OVSDB connection which is shared across all functionalities.

Another PRO point for us developers is that every time a new service is introduced we need to update then deployment tool to include it, create packages, containers etc...

In TripleO for example that means adding it to Tripleo Heat Templates, as well we Puppet repositories, etc...

A single agent saves us a lot of that work too.

This is in conflict with my understanding of ovn architecture. I believed that:

* NB DB has a global logical view, which changes (relatively) slowly and it has a very limited set of users (practically the cms and ovn-northd) therefore it's easy to scale
* SB DB has an in-detail physical view, which can change quickly, therefore it may be hard to scale, but at least 1) the scaling problems are localized to the SB DB, and 2) theoretically (but AFAIU not practically today) the SB DB could be sharded, that is one SB DB instance could handle only a subset of all chassis (plural).

If this is correct (is it? I'm not sure) then the agent proposed here should not directly read from the NB DB - just like ovn-controller does/should not.

You are right on this. The QoS information should be translated to the corresponding logical flows with their own matches and actions. But in this case this is not happening due to limitations in the driver. In order to read the min-bw values (that are not applied on the VF), we need to retrieve the Logical_Switch_Port register
Do we need any information in the neutron agent API about which agent is a real agent and which one is an agent-like representation of something else? I hope not. Just thinking out loud...

A note unrelated to this proposal to get feedback from knowledgable people: This is gonna change the number of connections at scale drastically. I'm not familiar much with Telco edge sites but I assume they can have hundreds of HWOL enabled nodes to host VNFs. Maybe someone with better edge knowledge than mine can chime in to discuss what numbers do we plan to work with. We will need to document this architectural change for scale environments.

There is always a balance between the new functionality and the scale. If they want to have QoS with HWOL, then they will need to use this new agent, increasing the DB connections.

I'll say that since [1], we can reduce to 1 the number of SB connections per OVN metadata agent. When moving the metadata functionality to this monitor, we'll have just one single NB and one SB connections to the database.

bandwidth ? Or rather "stored in QoS table in bandwidth:rate column key"
Right, QoS:bandwidth

Idea: The QoS table is a lot smaller than LSP table. I'm wondering if it's worth to monitor LSP table just to obtain the qos_min_rate value as this table can be in a number of tens of thousand of entries. If we, by the ovn mech driver, store this value as an external id in the QoS table along with LSP options then perhaps we can avoid having to monitor the LSP table completel?

I meant to write it to both places, LSP options for OVN and to QoS as a data storage, so we can pick the data without having to monitor LSP table, because of it's assumed size. Thanks to transactions we will have the rate set either in both places or nowhere.

From what I understoond, we need to set this "qos_min_rate" option in the LSP table for this to work. And, if we are writing that option we need to include the LSP table when we create the connection.

https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man5/ovn-nb.5.html

In OVN we have two types of QoS BW enforcement: using the kernel classes (linux "tc") or metering (NOTE1):
* max and burst use metering
* min uses linux traffic control (see [1])

QoS registers are translated into meter rules; LSP.options are used to set the interface TC settings. We can't use the QoS registers for the min-bw rules.

For now I'll keep using the LSP registers but it will be necessary to investigate a future improvement not to use them.

As Lucas suggested, I'll add this information to the "Performance Impact" section too.

NOTE1: if you check link [0], you'll see the metering feature has been implemented for mlnx cards. This is for connectx6 NICs, not connect5. But this is not solving the issue of the minimum BW feature, that is not implemented using metering (max and burst are) but using the linux traffic control implementation (HTB classful algorithm).

[1]https://github.com/ovn-org/ovn/commit/dbf12e5fe1f7ab2acef4152854c239b999b70188#diff-538df8a7fc4aa894586caf2191217e5d8a50bf245ee88faf90516a1c229cf42aR6347

BakedQuery is a legacy extension that no longer does too much beyond what SQLAlchemy 1.4 does in most cases automatically.  new development w/ BakedQuery is a non-starter, this is a legacy module we would eventually remove.

The only additional speed increase you might get here would be to use lambda expressions (https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/core/connections.html#using-lambdas-to-add-significant-speed-gains-to-statement-production), which I would in general not recommend, unless you had a really very specific and isolated case with a very simple statement.   lambda SQL has not turned out to be that forgiving if things go wrong.

A few things here:

1. Shouldn't you be checking "gsnapshot.status in ('d', 'e_d')" ? Right now you're testing whether the group snapshot object itself is in the tuple of strings.

2. actually, for #1, gsnapshot.status is the current status of the group snapshot, whereas what the caller wants to update to is contained in the 'status' variable. We don't need to have access to the gsnapshot when we do this check, so why don't you move it to before line 194:

  if status in ('deleting', 'error_deleting'):
      msg = _("Cannot reset-state to %s" % gsnapshot)
      raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg)

3. This change will break some of your unit tests (test_reset_group_snapshot_error_deleting_to_error_deleting and test_reset_group_snapshot_deleting_to_deleting), but I think that's OK.  What I mean is, I think it would be correct that an operator get a 400 for *any* attempt to reset-state to 'deleting' or 'error_deleting' regardless of the current status of the group snapshot.

Two things:

1. Shouldn't this be 'status' ?

2. I still think you should move lines 203-205 before the 'start' notification is set, and since you're just looking at the status that's in the request, you don't need to do this check inside the try block.  So I'd advise moving this to before line 197.

doc/source/admin/availability-zones.rst.message:
This is still true though. While we removed the force semantics from these APIs in API microversion 2.68 [1], it's still possible to do this with a previous microversion. You'd need to use older versions of openstackclient and novaclient but it's still possible to exercise these. For example, using an older (i.e. pre-v5.5.0 - we dropped this feature from OSC in v5.5.0 [2]) version of OSC:

  openstack server migrate --live <host> <server>

If you wanted to do this without forcing, you'd use:

    openstack server migrate --live-migration --host <host> <server>

Meanwhile, we only added support for 'server evacuate' commands to OSC in 5.5.0 [3] and therefore never exposed the ability to force a evacuation but it was previously possible with novaclient though:

  nova evacuate --force <server> <host>

Again, if you wanted to do this without forcing, you'd use:

  nova evacuate <server> <host>

or, better:

  openstack server evacuate --host <host> <server>

We could probably improve the wording here but I wouldn't remove this entirely. Hopefully the above is helpful in crafting something.

Also, in here, I would avoid defaulting to public port as in other roles we will have public port defaulting to internal and not the other way around which would cause confusion for operators overriding one but not the other.

I did this, because there are people, that would like to have each endpoint using the standard https port and a specific fqdn for each service - only on the internet facing front.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: LGTM

Hi Liam,

Why do we need to clear the 'charm.vaul.ca.ready'? Its not clear to me the effects of not doing it. From the charm comment:

"We have to clear both the reactive flag, as well as the leadership managed root-ca option, otherwise, we will end up with the flag being reset in the reactive handler after this is run."

But what is the difference from resetting it there or in get_intermediate_csrs?
Stepping back a bit, it seems logical to me that the current CA should still be valid until the upload of the new CSR is done, so we should find a way not to invalidate it until upload_signed_csr is run
I think we should have a unit test for this.
charm-recheck
just a minor nitpick.

I like the idea but I think it is a larger piece of work and is out of scope for this bug fix. The charm would have to track which csr went with which mount point and would have to track which was the current active mount point when issuing certs.

So, we can do that by creating a new mount point. New CSRs would be generated in the new mount point, not charm-pki-local, then, once the upload was done we could either copy it to charm-pki-local or just switch all operations to use that one. Pretty much like firmware updates does by using memory banks.

Do you forsee any problems with that approach?

Hi Erlon,

Thanking you for taking the time to review the patch. Generating a new csr for the intermediate CA wipes the CA in vault. This is vaults behaviour (rather than the charms) and it is noted here:https://www.vaultproject.io/api-docs/secret/pki#generate-intermediate . The reactive flags and leadership managed root-ca option need to be cleared to indicate to the charm that there is not longer a usable intermediate CA available.

I agree that it makes sense that the CA should remain valid until the signed csr is uploaded but that is unfortunately not how vault works.

I have added more code comments to the charm to attempt to make this all clearer.
charm-recheck
charm-recheck
LGTM

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
base_sha is actually fairly important.  Without it we are unable to correctly calculate the set of changed files.  The difference is and will be observable to users who will not understand why jobs they expect to run are not running, or the other way around.

What are the options for waiting until gitlab's async work is completed?

> I understand how it works, my point was that the fallback is only an approximation.  It will not return the correct set of files if the target branch has diverged from when the MR was originally written (and that happens all the time).  It is very frequently wrong enough that users notice and complain.  See 79b6252370568926e69610f752f2c2618a557341 for more information.

Ok, yes I understand what could the issue and why relying on the code review provider to give the base_sha is better.

> I'm intrigued by your other change, that approach would seem to let us continue to use the more accurate base_sha.  Were there problems with that?

Yes exactly. No, it seems the change will work well: gitlab's devs confirmed that the update event is only triggered after diff_refs is updated (and accurate) and the issue (diff_refs at None) only happens at MR creation. So yes if you think we should go with this other change I'm fine as well. So I've restored it.
Thanks, I think I like the other change better even though it's more complex.  Let's focus there for now.

I understand how it works, my point was that the fallback is only an approximation.  It will not return the correct set of files if the target branch has diverged from when the MR was originally written (and that happens all the time).  It is very frequently wrong enough that users notice and complain.  See 79b6252370568926e69610f752f2c2618a557341 for more information.

I'm intrigued by your other change, that approach would seem to let us continue to use the more accurate base_sha.  Were there problems with that?

Internally Zuul uses the merger's fileschanges task to compute the files diff between the PR Head and the target branch HEAD if base_sha is not provided (None). Thus the fix in the parent change. This is simulated in the tests (the additional addCommit) and validated on a test instance connected to gitlab.com.

An other option I've proposed but then abandonned for this one was https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/867804/

neutron/agent/l3/dvr_fip_ns.py.message:
So the unit here is ms (millisecond)？Why the value is 5? Is there a best practice?

A self-explain constant defination should be good for this number here, how about:

ARP_PROXY_DELAY_MS = 5

On the other hand, chaning the value of kernel gc_thresh, can be a workaround to overcome this? From my personal experiences, the network node which is serving large number of IPs should change the gc_thresh1/gc_thresh2/gc_thresh3 to higher value, especially when they are facing the internet directly.
Please make it a const as per LIU's suggestion
what is the unit of that? I just found that this setting defaults to 0.8 second, so is that 5 seconds now? Or 5 miliseconds? Or what exactly? Can You explain a bit more?

Hi Slaweq, the unit is jiffies where one jiffie is (typically) 100 meaning one jiffie is 0.01s. The defaults for this sysctl are:

ubuntu@focal:~$ sysctl net.ipv4.neigh.default.proxy_delay
net.ipv4.neigh.default.proxy_delay = 80

where

ubuntu@focal:~$ getconf CLK_TCK
100

i.e. default is 800ms and we are now setting to 50ms which feels like a more palatable max value.

Maybe we can hide this long stroy to a defination with suffix "_MS" here by inverse operation of kernel related algorithms.

def get_kernel_config_of_hz():
    return X

HZ = get_kernel_config_of_hz()

SYSCTL_ARP_PROXY_MAX_DELAY_MS = 50  (50 ms is our wanted value, so jiffies then will be based on the kernel HZ).

net.ipv4.neigh.%s.proxy_delay= (SYSCTL_ARP_PROXY_MAX_DELAY_MS / 1000) * HZ.

Quite curious this time unit (dependent on the arch https://www.netadmintools.com/html/7arp.man.html).

Maybe this value, if needed, could be a config knob (but only if needed, not now).

I think we could solve this whole problem by simply disabling it. It might be a sensible default but we know what software we're running, we don't need it, we should just disable it.

Calico appears to do exactly that (issue introducing the fix, the lines have changed, but it remains):
https://github.com/projectcalico/felix/issues/164

Just disable it and it resolves any issue surrounding unit calculations etc. That issue also suggests even having a smaller value can introduce extra unnecessary delay to the response.

I would note however there is apparently a kernel bug that can be triggered in such a case that we may need to be mindful of - it suggests to set proxy_delay -before- proxy_arp
https://github.com/torvalds/linux/commit/a533b70a657c03137dd49cbcfee70aac086ab2b1
https://github.com/projectcalico/felix/issues/1937

FWIW the reason for having proxy_delay at all seems lost to the sands of time, it seems pre-git (pre-2005) and there are multiple sources stating it's unclear why other than a comment to 'prevent looping in some cases' that is equally as old.

Looks a bit complicated based on the kernel implementation [1]. So it is a variable value based on different kernel version and hardware.
One example, if HZ = 1 tick(s)/sec, 5 jiffies will be 5 seconds. (never mind, just a simple example.)😊
There are some example in the kernel header: "100 Hz for the SunOS kernel, 256 Hz for the Ultrix kernel and 1024 Hz". So maybe in some deployment, "5" will not be the real value they want.

The delay value is variable not fixed, so the name here (with ARP) should be:

SYSCTL_ARP_PROXY_MAX_DELAY_JIFFIES = 5 (-1 for this)

[1] https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/include/linux/jiffies.h

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
So I guess I'm a little confused, given that we already have retry support. What this patch is really doing is allowing an explicit override to be declared and then passed down through by python method callers. Potentially in unsafe locations.

I guess I'm struggling to understand why this was needed when existing ipmi internal retrys[0], or the via an addition to the internal list of errors which we will automatically retry [1].

I guess my over arching concern is that explicit overrides might create conditions where an operator may exhaust resources on the conductor or potentially set BMCs into unsafe conditions, which means we ultimately need to better understand why, and if this is usable. Right now, only python code can leverage this.

[0]: https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/ironic/conf/ipmi.py#L40
[1]: https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/ironic/conf/ipmi.py#L64

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
This patch, as described in the commit message and as written, is not acceptable. We can't have python API for dictating how often to retry when we expose the values that calculate into that in configuration.

If you need (as mentioned in one of the other iRMC patches) the ability to do a ipmi request *with no retries at all*, that's acceptable, but it should have a default value of "True" and IMO should only be set in the few places you don't want retries -- like when checking to see if the IPMI interface is enabled at all.

ironic/drivers/modules/ipmitool.py.message:
from a python api standpoint, this is confusing. How does the ipmi command retry timeout relevant here? It *is* the overall timeout for all ipmi commands, it just seems weird to see it mentioned here. When reading, my mind also immediately thinks this implies the default.

I'd honestly keep it more vague. ":param num_tries: Number of IPMI operation command invocation retry attempts. Defaults to 0."

This should not even be exposed here, I think... or really throughout. Lets leave all the stuff about how and how often to retry in the config, with a toggle to "not retry" for cases where you need to do something you don't want retried (e.g. checking if IPMI is even enabled).
